caption: This is the most complete collection of military history I have seen in one place. Walking through the centuries of warfare and French influence around the globe through the methods and tools of war. It is amazing to see how the technology and methods have evolved over time. We spent over 7 hours here capping the visit off with the tomb of Napoleon. This elaborate resting place is both an example of the opulence of the French rulers and a reminder of the excess that the French people rose up against. A Mecca for military history buffs.

The Army Museum was a chance visit whilst passing by, and I'm glad we did. The amount of exhibits and military history on display was fascinating.  We could of spent hours here but time was against us as we had other engagements. Will be coming back again next year to fully take on the whole MuseumüòÅ

I found the Army Museum in Paris to be incredibly interesting and informative overall, but the highlight of my visit was seeing Napoleon‚Äôs tomb. It was absolutely impressive and left a lasting impression. The history surrounding it is fascinating, and it‚Äôs a must-see if you‚Äôre visiting the museum. I would highly recommend it to anyone interested in history.

Wowwww. A half day is NOT enough to explore this museum. Sooooo interesting. Especially with their multimedia that actually shows and explains war strategy. Very very interesting and really needs time. So if you plan to go and you like warfare and French history, allocate at least 4-6 hours.  Great place for photos too - which you don't need to pay for. Can enter the open area and second floor before the exhibits for free.

Such a great experience ! One of the largest military museums in the world. An impressive collection of artifacts spanning French military history from the Middle Ages to the present day.  The Mus√©e de l'Arm√©e is a must-visit for anyone interested in military history. The museum is well-organized and informative, and the exhibits are both fascinating and educational.  I recommend !

Amazing military meseum complete with little battle displays  of actual battles that was fought from different times.  A large collection of weapons, uniforms, and all sort of military items showcasing different eras.  A very complete and insightful museum that showcases all things french! Loved it and i will visit again!

We had an absolutely fantastic time visiting the Army Museum in Paris! This museum is a treasure trove of history, with an impressive collection that spans several centuries. From the moment we walked in, we were captivated by the breadth and depth of the exhibits, which cover everything from medieval armor to modern warfare.  One of the highlights for us was the stunning collection of armor and weaponry. The displays are incredibly well-preserved and presented in a way that really brings history to life. We also enjoyed exploring the sections dedicated to the World Wars, which were both informative and moving. The museum does an excellent job of combining historical artifacts with multimedia presentations to create a truly engaging experience.  For those planning a visit, I recommend setting aside at least 2-3 hours to fully appreciate everything, as the museum is quite large and there‚Äôs so much to see. Arriving early in the day can help you avoid the crowds, especially if you want to take your time in the more popular exhibits. Don‚Äôt miss the opportunity to visit Napoleon‚Äôs Tomb, which is part of the same complex and makes for a perfect combination with the museum. Consider getting the audio guide, which provides additional context and insights that really enhance the experience. Lastly, since there‚Äôs a lot of walking involved, be sure to wear comfortable shoes.  Overall, the Army Museum is a must-visit for anyone interested in military history or just looking for a unique cultural experience in Paris. We left with a deeper appreciation for history and a sense of awe at the incredible artifacts on display. Highly recommended!

One of the best museums to visit in Paris if you want to know their history. It perfectly portrays the history of france during World War 1 and World War 2. You get to know the evolution of France over the years. It is also one of the most beautiful museums you'll see in Paris and is a must visit when coming here. It'll take you around 3 hours to explore completely and you can have lunch in the two cafeterias inside the Museum. The entire museum is Marvelous. It also has tombs of some famous people and kings. A must visit place!

This museum is amazing. I never do research about museums before I go, so that everything is a surprise. I didn't realize that I was in for such a treat! The mixture of replicas, actual functional historical pieces, and historical art was amazing. The staff here are also very friendly and were super helpful when I had to ask for directions or accidentally wandered out of the wrong exit. This is a must-see for all history nerds who find themselves in Paris.

This was one of the most stunning places that I have been to in France. The museum itself is massive. I had planned on spending about three hours there and ended up spending the entire day. The amount of history that are inside of these chambers is unimaginable. I especially enjoyed learning about side of World War II. The medieval armor displays are amazing. The most breathtaking room to be in obviously is the tomb of Napoleon. It‚Äôs inside the dome. Unbelievable!

Lots to see, war museum showcasing history of wars France was involved in. Most interesting being Nepolian war time, showing his uniform, weapons etc. He is also laid to rest in the church. Beautiful church and grounds. 2-3 hours is enough to see all.

This museum is staggering in its size and quite poorly laid out. Such that you must backtrack so many times if you wanted to look everything. The good news is that you don‚Äôt need to look at everything, because there are hundreds of repeated objects. The format is not particularly coherent. I would recommend to this museum that less is more. Just because you have a thousand swords doesn‚Äôt mean they all need to be on display. The elevators are slow and inaccessible, the toilets are few and far between, and there‚Äôs only one place to borrow a wheelchair which makes getting one quite hard if you come in the Seine side (enter by Napoleons Tomb if you need a wheelchair). If you are able bodied, speak French (translations are limited) and have 8 hours that you want to spend looking at military stuff, this is the place for you. Napoleon‚Äôs tomb was much to opulent, although it was a sight to behold. The staff were all quite Onery and unhelpful. None of them cared that my wife was 28 weeks pregnant except one guy. Lady sweeping the bathroom wouldn‚Äôt even let her use it so she had to go a very long ways down a few floors to use the other one.
Amazing place. If you like military stuff, cannons, swords, armor and history. I spent 5 hrs there and will have to go back just to do the section on Napoleon.

The signage within Les Invalides is quite confusing, especially when trying to find the Military Museum. Visitors often struggle to figure out which direction to take, and the overall layout is poorly organized. With an entrance fee of 15‚Ç¨, many people miss out on important parts of the exhibit due to the unclear directions, which significantly impacts the experience.  Les Invalides, located in Paris, France, is a complex of buildings with historical and cultural significance, originally built as a hospital and retirement home for war veterans in 1671. Today, it houses the Military Museum (Mus√©e de l'Arm√©e), Napoleon‚Äôs Tomb, and other exhibitions related to French military history. The stunning architecture and the collection of military artifacts make it a key tourist attraction.
Highly recommended historic site. Gorgeous grounds. Napoleon's tomb and others close to him like his brother. Amazing WW II historic display. Largest display of armory I've ever seen.

My grandson and I visited the Army Museum after a bike tour because our guide recommended it and it was definitely worth the visit.  It is combination of  newly constructed museum connected to a beautiful ornate building where Napoleon's crypt is located.

An excellent museum, probably 3 or4 museums in one. The tomb of Napoleon is worth visiting on its own but the rest of the exhibits are worth your time. The fact you scan your ticket at each section was good as it means you can leave the site, go and get some lunch and go back.

There is a lot to see here. Lots of artifacts and information including Napoleon's hat and tomb. If you're a history buff plan to spend the full day here. You can get away with spending a couple of hours here if you don't dive into everything. You can buy tickets on site, and children are free with a paying adult. The cafe on site is good, but pricey.
Really good museum with some cool displays. The 3D Maps are amazing. Napoleon tomb was worth a visit. Give yourself plenty of time as there's a lot to see.
Napoleon‚Äô tomb is here. Also so many armor muskets, swords etc u can find here. There was a special event when we were there and touched Sherman tank too

Great museum, lots of information and many exhibitions. I can really recommend visiting Napoleon's tomb which is accessible with a museum ticket, his overinflated ego led to an astonishing monument. Food and drinks in the museum bar were very pricey (‚Ç¨5 for a coke).
I loved going back in time to see French history. My trois grandpere fought and seeing uniforms was very affirming for me. I would recommend it for anyone.

Great museum. Took the audio guide but in the end gave up because the menus on the audio guide were too difficult to navigate and I had no clue where I was in relation to the guide. So not worth renting the audio guide. The museum itself was excellent and they had a special floor about D Day.

It's wonderful that in the same place we could see the tomb of Napoleon Bonaparte, room of Charle de Gaulle, the uniforms and weapon of different √©poques and also the short documentary film showing us the history. The price of 14‚Ç¨ is good and children before 12 years is free

Best exhibition of military equipment (especially WW2) that I‚Äôve ever seen. Several immersive aspects of the exhibits with visuals, noise, immersive rooms, and more. Plenty to see. You can expect it to take 3+ hours if you‚Äôre semi-thorough.

Wonderful museum. So much to see if you are interested in military history throughout time in France and Europe.  Easily a few hours but you cannot really spend time at everything there is so much. One of my favorites in paris.
Honestly I‚Äôm not a super fan of army related things, I just showed up as a company. but I spent several hours here, it was so much fun!!

I visited the Army Museum in Paris last May, and honestly, it was amazing. The museum‚Äôs inside the H√¥tel des Invalides, which already gives you a cool, historical vibe as soon as you step in. The place is huge and full of everything from medieval armor to modern military gear ‚Äì like, you can spend hours here and still have more to see.  One thing not everyone knows is that this museum came together by merging two older ones back in 1905, making it one of the biggest military history museums around. there are over 500,000 items here, which is kind of mind-blowing! they even have these old relief maps ‚Äì the ‚ÄúPlans-Reliefs‚Äù ‚Äì which they used for military planning way back in the day. Pretty wild to think about.  And don‚Äôt miss the Dome Church while you‚Äôre here. that‚Äôs where Napoleon‚Äôs tomb is, and it‚Äôs really something to see. There‚Äôs this whole atmosphere there that just feels‚Ä¶ significant, you know?  If you‚Äôre into WWII stuff, they also have the Charles de Gaulle Monument, with some interactive displays that give you a peek into his life and what he did during the war.  Overall, I‚Äôd say if you‚Äôre into history or just want to see something truly unique, the Army Museum is a must. It‚Äôs packed with so much to look at and has this amazing historical feel.

This place turned out to be much more interesting than anticipated. Among other things, the swords, sabers, guns, and uniforms used by the army back in the 19th, 18th, and previous centuries were quite something to look at up close (especially the weapons and uniforms of high-ranking army officers). It was fun listening to a group of young children (under 10 years old) debating which sword was cooler and which one they liked most. Additionally, it just happened that some of the actual army was there getting ready for the celebration of Bastille Day (14/7). It was strange to encounter a whole whack of real army officers  while visiting the Army Museum.
username: Tina BQ Tran - Quintessential Energy Focus

caption: Good museum to visit while at "Les Invalides" (2  for 1: this museum and Napoleon's tomb). Many war artifacts and a good exhibition of "la resistance" during WW2.

We had a great time during the visit, which was cut short due to the military ceremony that took place. However, the ceremony made our visit more interesting and exciting thanks to the pageantry and music.
An amazing visit for my wife & i, we enjoy museums and this was one of the top ones we have visited.  There's plenty of things to see here, the only thing i wished was that we had more time!

The incredible place to watch. There are lots to see for free on the museum territory. But the staff if rude or may the problem is in Head office. I don't know why they locked the toilet and put a guard there who only let visitors with tickets in? The territory is huge, there is a lot of places to walk, look at exhibits, read interesting information, but if you want to go to the toilet, you have to leave there earlier. In addition, there is a store on the territory, and I did some shopping there, but I don't have access to the toilet. It's not a customer-oriented place at all.
Nice place and interesting things to see. It was a bit sad there wasn't much information in english and the place was not easy to navigate.

This is my favorite museum in Paris! The entire Invalides complex is lovely, including the museum, the cathedral, the dome above the tomb of Napoleon I, and the grounds. The ancient weapons and armor are a highlight, but don't miss the Museum of Plans-Reliefs, which is a fascinating collection of models of famous French sights.
So much to see the 2 hours we had planned was not enough.
Don't overlook this gem of a museum. Fascinating medieval collection. If you're a medievalist, you have to go.

I came to see the tomb of Napoleon I, but did not expect the museum to be loaded with good exhibits from medieval to WW2.  I highly recommend.  However,  there is only one bathroom by the entrance. Other bathrooms require fee.
